answer_html: Notice that this convers all possible values for \(\displaystyle 15+h\) and \(\displaystyle 3+k\).
answer_latex:
Notice that this convers all possible values for $\displaystyle 15+h$ and
$\displaystyle 3+k$.
hints_html:
Writing this system in matrix form, what will tell about the number of solutions?

Pick carefully which row manipulations you will do, they will simplify your calculations quite a bit.
hints_latex:
Writing this system in matrix form, what will tell about the number of
solutions?

Pick carefully which row manipulations you will do, they will simplify
your calculations quite a bit.
hints_raw:
Writing this system in matrix form, what will tell about the number of solutions?
Pick carefully which row manipulations you will do, they will simplify your calculations quite a bit.
sols_html:
We can write this system in matrix form:

\[\begin{aligned} \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 3 & 4 & 7 \\ -9 & 6 & 9 \\ 45 & -12 & h \end{array} \right] \left[ \begin{array}{c} x \\ y \\ z \end{array} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 3 \\ 3 \\ k \end{array} \right]\end{aligned}\]

To know the number of solutions, we want to look at the row reduced form of the augmented matrix.

First, perform the operations L3 \(\rightarrow\) L3+5L2 and L2 \(\rightarrow\) L2-3L1

\[\begin{aligned} \left[ \begin{array}{cccc} 3 & 4 & 7 & 3\\ -9 & 6 & 9 & 3\\ 45 & -12 & h & k \end{array} \right] \sim \left[ \begin{array}{cccc} 3 & 4 & 7 & 3 \\ 0 & 18 & 30 & 12 \\ 0 & 18 & 45 + h & 15+k \end{array} \right]\end{aligned}\]

Then, perform L3 \(\rightarrow\) L3 - L2

\[\begin{aligned} \sim \left[ \begin{array}{cccc} 3 & 4 & 7 & 3 \\ 0 & 18 & 30 & 12 \\ 0 & 0 & 15+h & 3+k \end{array} \right]\end{aligned}\]

Noting that the first two rows of the matrix give a matrix of rank at least 2, the number of solutions depend only on the last row. We read the last row of this matrix and we obtain the equation

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle (15+h)z = 3+k\end{aligned}\]

We can now read off the solutions from this equation base on whether or not \(15+h\) and \(3+k\) are equal to zero.

a) No solution if \(15+ h = 0, 3+k \ne 0\)

b) One solution if \(15+h \ne 0\)

c) Infinite solution if \(\displaystyle 15+ h = 0, 3+k = 0\)

Notice that this convers all possible values for \(\displaystyle 15+h\) and \(\displaystyle 3+k\).
sols_latex:
We can write this system in matrix form:

\begin{align*}
\left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
3 & 4 & 7 \\
-9 & 6 & 9 \\
45 & -12 & h
\end{array} \right] \left[ \begin{array}{c}
x \\
y \\
z
\end{array} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{c}
3 \\
3 \\
k
\end{array} \right]
\end{align*}

To know the number of solutions, we want to look at the row reduced form
of the augmented matrix.

First, perform the operations L\textsubscript{3} $\rightarrow$
L\textsubscript{3}+5L\textsubscript{2} and L\textsubscript{2} $\rightarrow$
L\textsubscript{2}-3L\textsubscript{1}

\begin{align*}
\left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
3 & 4 & 7 & 3\\
-9 & 6 & 9 & 3\\
45 & -12 & h & k
\end{array} \right] \sim \left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
3 & 4 & 7 & 3 \\
0 & 18 & 30 & 12 \\
0 & 18 & 45 + h & 15+k
\end{array} \right]
\end{align*} Then, perform L\textsubscript{3} $\rightarrow$
L\textsubscript{3} - L\textsubscript{2}

\begin{align*}
\sim \left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
3 & 4 & 7 & 3 \\
0 & 18 & 30 & 12 \\
0 & 0 & 15+h & 3+k
\end{array} \right]
\end{align*}

Noting that the first two rows of the matrix give a matrix of rank at
least 2, the number of solutions depend only on the last row. We read
the last row of this matrix and we obtain the equation

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
(15+h)z = 3+k
\end{align*}

We can now read off the solutions from this equation base on whether or
not $15+h$ and $3+k$ are equal to zero.

a) No solution if $15+ h = 0, 3+k \ne 0$

b) One solution if $15+h \ne 0$

c) Infinite solution if $\displaystyle 15+ h = 0, 3+k = 0$

Notice that this convers all possible values for $\displaystyle 15+h$ and
$\displaystyle 3+k$.
sols_raw:
We can write this system in matrix form:
:<math>
\left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
3 & 4 & 7 \\
-9 & 6 & 9 \\
45 & -12 & h
\end{array} \right] \left[ \begin{array}{c}
x \\
y \\
z
\end{array} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{c}
3 \\
3 \\
k
\end{array} \right]
</math>

To know the number of solutions, we want to look at the row reduced form of the augmented matrix.

First, perform the operations L<sub>3</sub> &rarr; L<sub>3</sub>+5L<sub>2</sub> and L<sub>2</sub> &rarr; L<sub>2</sub>-3L<sub>1</sub>
:<math>
\left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
3 & 4 & 7 & 3\\
-9 & 6 & 9 & 3\\
45 & -12 & h & k
\end{array} \right] \sim \left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
3 & 4 & 7 & 3 \\
0 & 18 & 30 & 12 \\
0 & 18 & 45 + h & 15+k
\end{array} \right]
</math>
Then, perform L<sub>3</sub> &rarr; L<sub>3</sub> - L<sub>2</sub> 
:<math>
\sim \left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
3 & 4 & 7 & 3 \\
0 & 18 & 30 & 12 \\
0 & 0 & 15+h & 3+k
\end{array} \right]
</math>

Noting that the first two rows of the matrix give a matrix of rank at least 2, the number of solutions depend only on the last row. We read the last row of this matrix and we obtain the equation
:<math>\displaystyle
(15+h)z = 3+k
</math>

We can now read off the solutions from this equation base on whether or not <math>15+h</math> and <math>3+k</math> are equal to zero.

a) No solution if <math>15+ h = 0, 3+k \ne 0</math>

b) One solution if <math>15+h \ne 0</math>

c) Infinite solution if <math>\displaystyle 15+ h = 0, 3+k = 0</math>

Notice that this convers all possible values for <math>\displaystyle15+h</math> and <math>\displaystyle3+k</math>.
statement_html:
Consider the system of linear equations:

\[\begin{aligned} 3x &\ +& 4y &\ +& 7z &\ &= 3\\ -9x &\ +& 6y &\ +& 9z &\ &= 3\\ 45x &\ -& 12y &\ +& hz &\ &= k\end{aligned}\]

For which values of h and k does the system have:

a) no solutions?

b) exactly one solution?

c) infinitely many solutions?
statement_latex:
Consider the system of linear equations:

\begin{align*}
3x &\ +& 4y &\ +& 7z &\ &= 3\\
-9x &\ +& 6y &\ +& 9z &\ &= 3\\
45x &\ -& 12y &\ +& hz &\ &= k
\end{align*} For which values of \emph{h} and \emph{k} does the system
have:

a) no solutions?

b) exactly one solution?

c) infinitely many solutions?
statement_raw:
Consider the system of linear equations:
:<math>
\begin{align}
3x &\ +& 4y &\ +& 7z &\ =& 3\\
-9x &\ +& 6y &\ +& 9z &\ =& 3\\
45x &\ -& 12y &\ +& hz &\ =& k
\end{align}
</math>
For which values of ''h'' and ''k'' does the system have:

a) no solutions?

b) exactly one solution?

c) infinitely many solutions?
